docs.lead_paragraph: If scientists want to develop new supplies of embryonic stem cells, they may have to take the bold and controversial step of creating human embryos expressly for research, many leading fertility experts say. Tens of thousands of embryos are frozen at fertility centers, and a widespread assumption in the debate over stem cell research has been that scientists can use them.

headline.main: RESEARCHERS SAY EMBRYOS IN LABS AREN'T AVAILABLE

docs.abstract: Leading fertility experts dispute widespread assumption in debate over stem cell research that scientists can use some of thousands of embryos frozen at fertility centers; say almost every embryo is spoken for, because vast majority of couples use their frozen embryos, or plan to use them, in attempts at pregnancy; say very few couples agree to donate embryos; alternative is to create human embryos and nurture them solely for experiments that would destroy them, but this leaves even many supporters of research deeply uneasy; photo (M)
docs.snippet: If scientists want to develop new supplies of embryonic stem cells, they may have to take the bold and controversial step of creating human embryos expressly for research, many leading fertility experts say.    Tens of thousands of embryos are frozen...

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1997, Tim B. Wride, an associate curator of photography at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, got an irresistible offer. ''I got this great phone call one afternoon from a buddy of mine who said, 'Tim, I'm going to Cuba, want to go?' '' Mr. Wride said. ''It was a fluke. The price was right, the timing was right, everything just fell into place.''
docs.abstract: Mike Hale reviews exhibition of Cuban photography after revolution on view at Los Angeles County Museum; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: VICTOR MANUEL HERRERA knows that proving that his newborn son was a human being and not a fetus will not add one second to the sentence of the police officer whose minivan killed his pregnant wife, his 4-year-old son and his sister-in-law. Mr. Herrera knows that the debate about when life begins may be hijacked by those on both sides of the abortion chasm.

headline.main: Has a Life Ended if It Never Really Began?

docs.abstract: Felicia Lee Coping column on quest by Victor Manuel Herrera to have newborn son, Ricardo Nicanol, recognized as fourth victim of August 4 accident that claimed lives of his pregnant wife, Maria, 4-year-old son and sister-in-law; baby was delivered by emergency Caesarean section to dead wife but pronounced dead less than 12 hours later; New York City Police Officer Joseph Gray, who allegedly ran red light while driving drunk, has been charged with vehicular homicide; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Before she had a ship, before she had any money for a ship or a nurse to go with the ship or a media representative to handle all the reporters who would want to know what she was doing with the ship, Dr. Rebecca Gomperts had an idea. It was 1997, and she was a 31-year-old abortion doctor based in Amsterdam, and to her, the idea seemed straightforward and reasonable, as so many ideas do before they take on the weight of reality. She wanted to buy a ship and sail it around the world, providing abortions at sea for women who could not otherwise get them. Gomperts, whose activist roots stem from a stint as the resident doctor on Greenpeace's Rainbow Warrior II boat, planned to visit countries where the procedure is either illegal or highly restricted and transport women seeking abortions into international waters, 12 miles offshore. There, a Dutch-registered ship would be subject to Dutch law, and she could legally perform abortions -- something she intended to do free. ''In my trips with Greenpeace, I became aware of the enormous and invisible suffering of women due to illegal abortions,'' Gomperts says. ''To me, this is a basic human rights issue.'' The first time Gomperts articulated her idea publicly outside the Netherlands -- in an interview with Ms. magazine last spring -- it generated headlines in four different countries, and the death threats started rolling in. When word of Gomperts's idea reached the island nation of Malta, where abortion is illegal, government officials vowed to prosecute anyone who assisted the Dutch doctor. The Web site Gomperts put up for her newly minted nonprofit organization, the Women on Waves Foundation, was promptly hijacked, redirecting visitors to a site that pictured bloody fetuses. More than once, Gomperts has been called a dangerous woman. One anti-abortion group has suggested she's a pirate.
docs.abstract: Article on Dr Rebecca Gomperts, Dutch abortion doctor and founder of Women on Waves Foundation, who faced storm of controversy over her idea to buy ship and sail it around world, performing free abortions at sea for women from countries where procedure is either illegal or highly restricted; Gomperts, viewed as movement's first extremist, failed to raise $1 million she needed to buy and equip her own ship but leased sport fishing boat and embarked on one-month pilot project to Dublin, Ireland; it is hard to say if Gomperts failed or succeeded in Ireland, since she was not granted permit to perform abortions before sailing from Amsterdam and, therefore, did not perform any; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was a typical scene for any beach on a warm summer's day. A half-dozen children squealed gleefully as they slowly unearthed what appeared to be an enormous fishing net that somehow washed ashore and became buried in the sand. Shouts of ''Mommy, Mommy, look!'' alternated with near-hysterical screams every time a wave came crashing onto shore and threatened to wash away their big dig.
docs.abstract: Article on rise in number children seen on beach at Fire Island's Cherry Grove, which has been traditionally gay and lesbian community since 1920's; factors include rise in number of lesbian and gay couples who have chosen to start their own families and increase in number of straight families traveling there for day trips; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Santana Moss sustained the knee injury that will shelve him until midseason, the Jets' special-teams coach, Mike Westhoff, who had counted on Moss to inject a spark into a dormant kick-return game, said he would move on to Plan B. Today, Plan B finally arrived when the Jets acquired the New Orleans running back and returner Chad Morton in a trade for cornerback Earthwind Moreland and a sixth-round draft pick in 2002. The Jets expect Morton to return kickoffs and punts Saturday against the Giants.
docs.abstract: New York Jets acquire New Orleans Saints' running back and returner Chad Morton in trade for cornerback Earthwind Moreland and sixth-round draft pick in 2002; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Maybe Baby,'' Ben Elton's fearless and funny comedy about infertility, is all but stolen by the British comic Rowan Atkinson in the small role of an alarmingly enthusiastic gynecologist. Disclosing the results of an unpleasant internal examination, the beaming doctor exclaims delightedly to his patient, Lucy Bell (Joely Richardson), that she has ''super guts,'' then rushes on to compliment her on the magnificence of her bowel and stool. This is the same specialist who in an earlier scene is shown proudly exhibiting his instruments to a wide-eyed student doctor with the glee of a sadist showing off tools of torture while Lucy, who is about to be probed, watches anxiously from the examination table. The British romantic comedy, which opens today at the Village East, is far from the first movie to explore infertility and the harrowing extremes to which childless couples can go nowadays to try to conceive. But it may be the first to blend traditionally romantic screen conventions with a clinical humor that radically desentimentalizes the rituals surrounding conception.

headline.main: Learning About the Birds, The Bees and the Petri Dishes

docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews British movie Maybe Baby, written and directed by Ben Elton from his novel; Hugh Laurie and Joely Richardson star, along with Rowan Atkinson and others; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Treatment Action Campaign, a group that lobbies on AIDS issues, asked a High Court judge to order the government to distribute the AIDS drug Nevirapine widely to pregnant women who are infected with H.I.V. The government has already begun small-scale distribution of the drug, which sharply reduces a pregnant woman's risk of transmitting the virus to her newborn. The Treatment Action Campaign says that the government program is too small and that officials have taken too long to get it running. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: AIDS Drug Sought
